properties.name: 1st Ohio Battery, [James] McNutt Hill
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryAt least two cannon were placed on McNutt Hill, now the O\'More College of Design, directly behind Stiles\' Brigade. The 1st Ohio artillery rained down shot and shell upon the approaching Confederate brigades led by Featherston, Adams and Scott. These guns fired over 1,100 rounds in just four hours.

properties.name: Collins Farm
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryLoring\'s Division (CSA) with the Brigades of Scott, Adams and Featherston crossed over Collins Farm on November 30th to make the assault against Stiles\' Brigade on the far Union Eastern flank. Loring\'s men faced withering shot and shell from the 1st Ohio Artillery in McNutt\'s Hill. Hundreds of Loring\'s men lost their lives and are now buried in McGavock Confederate Cemetery.

properties.name: Franklin Battlefield (future National Park)
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Country Club of Franklin Golf Course has been purchased by private preservation groups in Williamson County. The entire golf course will be converted into a restored battlefield on what was the Eastern Flank.

properties.name: Harpeth River
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harpeth River snaked around downtown Franklin, providing a natural protection of Federal rear, as well as the Western and Eastern Flanks.

properties.name: Harrison House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harrison House is just south of Winstead Hill on Columbia Pike. General John Bell Hood met in the parlor here with his commanders on the early afternoon of November 30, 1864. His subordinates did not want to make the assault that was forthcoming.

properties.name: July 10th, 1863 - First Assault on Fort Wagner
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryCWSAC summary - On July 10, Union artillery on Folly Island together with Rear Adm. John Dahlgren’s fleet of ironclads opened fire on Confederate defenses of Morris Island. The bombardment provided cover for Brig. Gen. George C. Strong’s brigade, which crossed Light House Inlet and landed by boats on the southern tip of the island. Strong’s troops advanced, capturing several batteries, to within range of Confederate Fort Wagner. At dawn, July 11, Strong attacked the fort. Soldiers of the 7th Connecticut reached the parapet but, unsupported, were thrown back. http://www.nps.gov/history/hps/abpp/battles/sc005.htm

properties.name: July 10th, 1863 - Morgan's Raid of Salem Indiana
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryConfederate cavalry under John Hunt Morgan had departed Kentucky on what became known as Morgan\'s Raid. Morgan reached Salem on July 10, 1863, coming north from Corydon. Upon entering Salem at 9 a.m.,, Morgan immediately took possession of the town and placed guards over the stores and streets. The cavalrymen burned the large brick railroad depot, along with all the cars on the track and the railroad bridges on each side of the town. Morgan demanded taxes from the two flour mills that belonged to DePaw and Knight, and from the Allen Wollen Mill. Morgan\'s men looted stores and took about 00 from the area before departing about 3 p.m.

properties.name: July 11th, 1862 - Battle of Rich Mountain, WV
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe Battle of Rich Mountain took place on July 11, 1861, in Randolph County, Virginia (now West Virginia) as part of the Operations in Western Virginia Campaign during the American Civil War. Wikipedia CWSAC - http://www.nps.gov/history/hps/abpp/battles/wv003.htm http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Battle_of_Rich_Mountain

properties.name: July 11th, 1862 - Maj. Gen. Henry W. Halleck named General-in-Chief
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryAfter Halleck\'s success at Corinth (April 29 - June 10th - Lincoln named him General-in-Chief of all U.S. land forces. CWSAC Corinth summary - http://www.nps.gov/history/hps/abpp/battles/ms016.htm

properties.name: July 11th, 1863 - First Assault on Fort Wagner
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryWikipedia excerpt The first engagement, the Battle of Fort Wagner or the First Assault on Morris Island, occurred on July 11, 1863. Only 12 Confederate soldiers were killed, as opposed to the Union\'s 330 losses. The second engagement is better known. The Battle of Fort Wagner, Morris Island, was the Union attack on July 18, 1863, led by the 54th Massachusetts Volunteer Infantry, one of the first major American military unit made up of black soldiers. Colonel Robert Gould Shaw led the 54th Regiment on foot while they charged and was killed in the assault. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fort_Wagner

properties.name: July 6th - Lincoln replaces Du Pont with Adm. John A. Dahlgren
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory1600 Pennsylvania ave, washington, D.C.Dahlgren replaces Du Pont as head of the Federal South Atlantic Blockading Squadron. Du Pont and Sec of Navy Welles had been arguing over the failure of an attack on Charleston. Read about Du Pont in Wikiepedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuel_F._Du_Pont Read about Dahlgren in Wikipedia http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_A._Dahlgren

properties.name: July 7th, 1863 - Bragg (CSA) encamps around Chattanooga
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryBy mid-1862 Braxton Bragg\'s Army of Tennessee (CSA) had lost most of Tennessee to Gen William S. Rosecrans Army of the Cumberland. By July 7th, Bragg was encamped around Chattanooga.

properties.name: July 7th, 1863 - Lee’s retreat from Gettysburg draws action in Williamsport
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryAccording to the CWSAC summary: During the night of July 4-5, Lee’s battered army began its retreat from Gettysburg, moving southwest on the Fairfield Road toward Hagerstown and Williamsport, screened by Stuart’s cavalry. The Union infantry followed cautiously the next day, converging on Middletown, Maryland. On July 7, Imboden (CS) stopped Buford’s Union cavalry from occupying Williamsport and destroying Confederate trains. Kilpatrick’s cavalry division drove two Confederate cavalry brigades through Hagerstown before being forced to retire by the arrival of the rest of Stuart’s command. Lee’s infantry reached the rain-swollen Potomac River but could not cross, the pontoon bridge having been destroyed by a cavalry raid. Wikipedia - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_D._Imboden

properties.name: July 8th, 1863 - Morgan's Raiders in Brandenburg, KY
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryJohn Hunt Morgan (CSA) and his men reaching the Cummings\' Ferry and Brandenburg, KY near the Ohio River as they planned to move into Indiana. Many feared Morgan\'s Raiders would stir up Copperhead supporters during his raid, causing quite a sensation among civilians.

properties.name: July 8th, 1863 - Surrender of Port Hudson, LA
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe siege of Port Hudson affected the Civil War and the men who fought there in a number of ways. The surrender gave the Union control of the Mississippi River, cutting off important states such as Arkansas and Texas. Both sides suffered heavy casualties: about 5,000 Union men were killed or wounded, and an additional 4,000 fell prey to disease or sunstroke; Gardner\'s forces suffered around 700 casualties, several hundred of whom died of disease. And on both sides, even many of those who survived found their view of war permanently changed. Wikipedia

properties.name: July 9th, 1862 - Battle of Tomkinsville, KY
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryMorgan\'s Raiders - First Kentucky Raid During the Civil War, both Union and Confederate forces sought control over Monroe County and especially Tompkinsville. The first part of 1862 saw an increased number of Confederates in the area. The Union, trying to maintain supremacy in this part of the state, sent four companies of the Ninth Pennsylvania Cavalry to Tompkinsville. They were led by Major Thomas Jefferson Jordan, had 230 soldiers, and contained a large supply train. Confederate Colonel John Hunt Morgan was launching his famous "First Kentucky Raid" and his first objective was the destruction of the Union forces in Tompkinsville. Morgan and his raiders left Celina, Tennessee on July 8th at 10:00 PM and marched all night to surprise his foe. The early morning of July 9, 1862, the peaceful little town of Tompkinsville was awakened by the thunder of cannon fire. At 5:00am the Confederate forces surprised and surrounded the Union garrison. The raiders positioned two cannons and fired into the camp, then carried it by a dashing charge. Within two hours the battle was over. The Confederates had captured the garrison and many Union soldiers, including Major Jordan. This, Morgan\'s first raid, yielded 20 wagons, 50 mules, 40 cavalry horses, supplies of sugar, coffee, etc. Union and Confederate reports contradict each other as to the tactics, number of troops, injuries, and fatalities of the battle. The following, official reports written by the commanding officers, best describe the battle. They are copied from War of the Rebellion, Records of the Union and Confederate Armies, Series I Vol. XVI.

properties.name: July 9th, 1863 - Battle of Corydon, Morgan's Raid
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe Battle of Corydon took place July 9, 1863, in Harrison County, Indiana, during Morgan\'s Raid in the American Civil War. It was the only Civil War battle in Indiana and resulted in a Confederate victory, which enabled Brig. Gen. John Hunt Morgan to secure supplies and money before turning eastward to Ohio. Wikipedia CWSAC - http://www.nps.gov/history/hps/abpp/battles/in001.htm

properties.name: July 9th, 1863 - Seige of Port Hudson
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe Siege of Port Hudson occurred in the summer of 1863 when 30,000 Union Army troops surrounded the Mississippi River town of Port Hudson, Louisiana. This attack, in cooperation with the attack on Vicksburg, was intended to take the Mississippi River away from the Confederates. The 6,500 Confederate Army soldiers defending the town were able to hold off the Union offensive for 48 days. The Confederate troops surrendered once Vicksburg had fallen. Some 5,000 Union men and 700 Confederate soldiers were killed or wounded during the siege. Wikipedia CWSAC - http://www.nps.gov/history/hps/abpp/battles/la010.htm

properties.name: July 9th, 1864 - Battle of Monocacy Junction
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe Battle of Monocacy (also known as Monocacy Junction) was fought on July 9, 1864, just outside Frederick, Maryland, as part of the Valley Campaigns of 1864, in the American Civil War. Confederate forces under Lt. Gen. Jubal A. Early defeated Union forces under Maj. Gen. Lew Wallace. The battle was part of Early’s raid through the Shenandoah Valley and into Maryland, attempting to divert Union forces away from Gen. Robert E. Lee’s army under siege at Petersburg, Virginia. Wikipedia article

properties.name: McGavock Confederate Cemetery
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe McGavock Confederate Cemetery is the largest privately owned military and Confederate Cemetery in the United States. 1,481 Confederate soldiers are buried here. http://www.McGavockCemetery.net

properties.name: Nashville-Decatur Railroad
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Nashville-Decatur Railroad runs North-South through Franklin. It runs right up against the Harpeth River (north/south) very close to Leesburg Pike. The combination of the railroad track and the Harpeth River here made the far Union Eastern Flank quite secure. Hood rejected the idea of a flanking attack by Nathan Bedford Forrest because of these natural protections for the Union Army.

properties.name: Position of Casement's Brigade
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryCasement\'s Brigade, Reilley\'s Division, 23rd Corps, was position here the day of the battle; made up of (R/L) the 124th Indiana, the 65th IL and the 65th Indiana, with the 5th TN in the rear.

properties.name: Position of Federal Army, Nov 30, 1864
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Federal Army had arrived in Franklin around 1:00 that morning. Brigadier General Jacob Dolson Cox led the operation and woke up the Carter family, commandeering their home as his headquarters. At that time, the Carter Farm consisted of 288 acres on the south edge of town bordering the Columbia Pike. Their cotton gin was located 100 yards from the house where eventually the main line of Federal breastworks were constructed. The Federal line commander was Cox who supervised his army in a defensive position surrounding the southern edge of town. He used the existing breastworks built in 1863 and constructed others on the west side of Columbia Pike. About 60 feet from the Carter House, near their farm office and smokehouse, were the inner breastworks.

properties.name: Position of Federal Artillery
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe 6th Ohio Artillery was placed just East of the Cotton Gin. The 104th Ohio Infantry to the immediate West, and 1st KY Artillery further to the West against Columbia Pike. The 100th Ohio was several yards direct north of the 1st KY artillery.

properties.name: Position of far Western Union flank
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryPosition of far Western Union flank protected by the 84th Indiana and the 2nd PA Artillery

properties.name: Position of the 120th Indiana
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe 120th Indiana (Stiles\' Brigade) had the far most Eastern Union flank position on the field. To their right was the 63rd Indiana, and further right (south west) was the 128th Indiana. The Confederate Brigades of Featherston, Scott and Adams approached this position from the South.

properties.name: The Carnton Plantation
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryCarnton Plantation is a historic home and museum in beautiful Williamson County, Tennessee. It was the largest filed-hospital used after the Battle of Franklin on November 30, 1864. The McGavock\'s owned the home.

properties.name: The Carter Cottin Gin
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryThe site of the Carter Cotton Gin saw some of the fiercest fighting on Nov 30, 1864. At that time, the Carter Farm consisted of 288 acres on the south edge of town bordering the Columbia Pike. Their cotton gin was located 100 yards from the house where eventually the main line of Federal breastworks were constructed.

properties.name: The Carter House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory Now a museum and preserved historical grounds; the farm was originally owned by Fountain Branch Carter in 1864. The site was the epicenter of the Battle between the Union forces under John M. Schofield and Confederate troops under John Bell Hood. The 44th Mississouri was placed right in front of the Carter House, facing south. The 50th Ohio and the 72nd Illinois (Strickland\'s Brigade) were several yards south and in front of the 44th MO.

properties.name: The Harpeth River - Eastern Union Flank
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Harpeth River snakes around downtown Franklin. The Harpeth River and the Nashville-Decatur Railroad provided a natural obstacle and protection to the Union far left flank during the Battle of Franklin. When Schofield first arrived with his army on the morning of November 30th, having just marched 12 miles south from Spring Hill, he found the only two bridges crossing the Harpeth at this point burned. His men set to rebuilding the bridges.

properties.name: The Lotz House
properties.description: Posted by Tellinghistory The Albert Lotz House, built in the late 1850s, sits here. The Lotz family sought protection the night of the battle in the basement of Fountain Branch Carter, just a few yards southwest and on the west side of Columbia Pike.

properties.name: Winstead Hill
properties.description: Posted by TellinghistoryJohn Bell Hood stood at this hill looking north toward downtown Franklin on the afternoon of November 30, 1864. He saw the entire Union line spread out from Carter\'s Creek Pike to his left (west), all the way to the east where the 120th Indiana was pressed up against the Nashville-Decatur RR. The rebels organized their troops, some 19,000 here at Winstead, and began the assault of the Union army, having to cross open ground of about two miles before finally reaching the Federal line of defended breastworks.
